Here's the result of running `cat -n` on /tmp/tmpj79ghnjj/sympy/sympy/core/function.py:
     1	"""
     2	There are three types of functions implemented in SymPy:
     3	
     4	    1) defined functions (in the sense that they can be evaluated) like
     5	       exp or sin; they have a name and a body:
     6	           f = exp
     7	    2) undefined function which have a name but no body. Undefined
     8	       functions can be defined using a Function class as follows:
     9	           f = Function('f')
    10	       (the result will be a Function instance)
    11	    3) anonymous function (or lambda function) which have a body (defined
    12	       with dummy variables) but have no name:
    13	           f = Lambda(x, exp(x)*x)
    14	           f = Lambda((x, y), exp(x)*y)
    15	    The fourth type of functions are composites, like (sin + cos)(x); these work in
    16	    SymPy core, but are not yet part of SymPy.
    17	
    18	    Examples
    19	    ========
    20	
    21	    >>> import sympy
    22	    >>> f = sympy.Function("f")
    23	    >>> from sympy.abc import x
    24	    >>> f(x)
    25	    f(x)
    26	    >>> print(sympy.srepr(f(x).func))
    27	    Function('f')
    28	    >>> f(x).args
    29	    (x,)
    30	
    31	"""
    32	from __future__ import print_function, division
    33	
    34	from .add import Add
    35	from .assumptions import ManagedProperties, _assume_defined
    36	from .basic import Basic
    37	from .cache import cacheit
    38	from .compatibility import iterable, is_sequence, as_int, ordered
    39	from .decorators import _sympifyit
    40	from .expr import Expr, AtomicExpr
    41	from .numbers import Rational, Float
    42	from .operations import LatticeOp
    43	from .rules import Transform
    44	from .singleton import S
